awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Collision Regulations (COLREG) Aware Autonomy for Safe Interactions of Crewed and Uncrewed Vessels
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to advance the productivity and safety of operations across the entire $1.3 trillion Blue Economy. Maritime operations routinely involve significant risks to human life and property and consequently bear extraordinarily high operating costs. Autonomous ocean vehicles (falling under the Robotics technology area) are being rapidly adopted by science, commercial, and defense organizations due to their potential to dramatically reduce cost and risk. The success of the proposed project will advance the state of the art for commercial autonomous vehicle compliance with international laws regulating interactions between maritime vessels at sea. Giving autonomous ocean vehicles the ability to interact with crewed vessels safely and predictably will accelerate the adoption of these tools and the missions they enable. Several specific market segments stand to benefit immediately from the proposed technology, including the $31B offshore wind market, the $2B port automation market, the $233B aquaculture market, and dozens of others. Beyond market impacts, humanity needs ocean data to understand the critical dangers of overfishing and climate change.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is focused on the design of systems and software needed for autonomous ocean vehicles to comply with the international collision regulations (COLREGS) for maritime vehicles. The difficulty the industry has faced in creating COLREGS compliant autonomy is the fact that the rules were developed with the expectation that experienced mariners would be able to make qualitative interpretations in unique situations. That led to a descriptive rather than prescriptive set of rules that is good for human mariners, but difficult to implement in software. The objectives of this Phase I project include the design and simulation of autonomous systems able to operate in compliance with the COLREGS. In addition to simulations, the software may be deployed to small autonomous surface vehicles for preliminary on-water testing. Anticipated results include a system able to maintain COLREGS compliance within a documented envelope of conditions. The effective implementation of safe system design, optimized control, and machine learning techniques can combine to produce the first autonomous ocean vehicles that can be trusted in congested waterway settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The ocean economy has been steadily growing in scale, competition, and urgency over the last several decades. Climate change and increasing global competition have accelerated the growth of multibillion-dollar ocean industries such as offshore wind, shipping, and fishing. All of these industries are increasingly trying to leverage autonomous vehicles for cost and risk reduction.  Similarly, to the aerial drone market, which boomed due to applications in surveying, recreational photography, and defense before the FAA?s regulations caught up to the technology, the maritime drone market is in a boom phase, but the regulatory environment is uncertain. One of the main hurdles to overcome is how to adapt the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGS) for autonomous vehicles, or how autonomous vehicles will evolve to comply with COLREGS.

SeaSatellites, Inc. (Seasats) is on a mission to make autonomous surface vehicles (ASVs) a standard, dependable part of the ocean landscape. As part of that mission, the company has developed and deployed market-leading small autonomous vehicles. The success of these platforms and increased market adoption places Seasats and its vehicles squarely in the discussion of how to safely and responsibly transition into a future where robots and people operate in tandem on the ocean.

Supported by this NSF SBIR Phase I award, Seasats researched and developed viable approaches for the growing class of small ASVs to be able to safely and economically abide by COLREGS. During the Phase I project timeline Seasats completed hundreds of hours of autonomous vehicle operations, simulated thousands of mission hours, closed over $1 million in sales, and raised over $10 million in investment. A brief summary of the major technical objectives completed are as follows:

1. Completed an analysis of COLREG scenarios, settings, and typical obstacles. The analysis was specifically focused on scenarios involving full autonomous, COLREG compliant, operations with small ASVs. By nature of focusing on small ASVs, the almost-infinite number of potential scenarios based on waterway types, vessel interactions, and rules in effect were broken down into sub-blocks of actionable categories for evaluating relevant sensors and algorithms.

 

2. Conducted a comparative survey of sensors that could serve small ASVs in COLREG compliant autonomy. The survey had a unique perspective in that it considered many factors including the price of sensors, the completeness of the sensing solution, the relevant environment it could impact, the weight, and the power requirements of the sensor.

 

3. Developed a novel and practical framework for implementing COLREG aware autonomy on small ASVs. Specifically, it provides a new take that considers COLREGS from an outcome-based perspective. The merits of this approach are that it lends itself both to easy judgement for humans, who will indeed be the final arbiters of the system, as well as to easy data-driven training and modeling for a machine learning based approach.   

 

4. Collected data over hundreds of hours of autonomous operations. This data contained real world AIS tracks, vessel interactions, and camera footage. While Objective 4 in the original Phase I plan sought to simulate sensors, the value of real world vessel-to-robot interactions was deemed to outweigh the value of engineering simulations for sensors. 

To conclude Phase I, the findings of the above objectives were reviewed, condensed, and summarized with the perspective of trying to advance COLREG compliant autonomy for small autonomous surface vehicles. Among the findings were a set of recommendations, noted limitations, and a proposed framework for extending this Phase I project into a Phase II project that would seek to implement and demonstrate multiple cases of COLREG compliant autonomy implemented on small ASVs.

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2023
Modified by: Michael Flanigan
